awd_titl_txt: Water-driven Glass Transition Dynamics in Polyelectrolyte Complexes and Multilayers
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Charged polymers (polyelectrolytes) impact society in areas ranging from personal care and energy to health care. These polymers bear a charged group that can associate with oppositely charged macromolecules to form a larger superstructure called a polyelectrolyte complex. The nature of how these polyelectrolytes associate is represented by the number of associations or electrostatic crosslinks, which in turn influences the physical properties of the complex. One important challenge is that these complexes should bear desired properties at real-world conditions, such as certain relative humidity values and temperatures. However, there remains a lack of understanding regarding how and why water and temperature dictate the thermal and mechanical properties of a given complex. One significant challenge is that it is not clear how these physical properties connect to the original structure of the electrostatically crosslinked polyelectrolyte complex. This project addresses this challenge by examining the dynamics and mobility of the polyelectrolyte and of water within the structure at varying environmental conditions. These findings will be compared to the structure of the complex and physical properties such as stiffness. The knowledge developed in this project could lead to a predictive relationship that may broadly describe the physical properties of any complex in response to environmental conditions. The proposed work offers several opportunities for educational enrichment of a broad spectrum of members of the general public. The educational objectives and broader impact for this work include: hands-on research opportunities for undergraduates, K-12 outreach through TAMU's Chemistry Open House through demonstrations to the public, Science Night demonstrations at local elementary schools, and online outreach through the EngineerGirl website.


PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Cultivating a deeper understanding of the physical properties of polyelectrolyte complexes as they connect to the complex's structure is an important challenge for advancing their wider application. However, this understanding is complicated by complex factors such as the electrostatic crosslinking density, water content, and temperature. For example, it is known that the glass transition temperature (Tg) is intimately tied to the water content and ion pairing within the complex, which is in turn influenced by salt and/or pH. However, the current understanding is somewhat empirical or qualitative, and a quantitative connection to a physical dynamic process is needed. The central goal of this project is to elucidate the physical origin of the glass transition-ion pairing-water relationship via characterization of the glass transition dynamics and the molecular structure of the complex. This will be accomplished by spectroscopic characterization, dynamic mechanical analysis, and thermal analysis. These complexes will be further explored for their stiffness at different time scales, temperatures, and humidity values. The central hypothesis is that the dynamics of the polymer chain are influenced by water mobility at the electrostatic crosslink and by the association/dissociation of the crosslink itself. Water may lubricate the electrostatic crosslink and promote temporary dissociation of the electrostatic crosslink. One significant outcome of this work is possibly a new physics-based understanding that quantitatively connects the structure of a complex and the surrounding environmental conditions to the resultant physical properties of that complex.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polyelectrolyte complexes (PECs, Figure 1), which form when oppositely charged polymers associate to create a larger structure, are experiencing a renaissance, spurred by new processing approaches and applications. These postive-negative associations between the oppositely charged polymers are called “ion-pairs.” The last decade has witnessed processing advances in “saloplastics”, electrospinnable, and 3D printable complexes for a range of applications. In the presence of moisture, these materials have a characteristic temperature at which they soften, transforming them from brittle to soft and processable. This characteristic temperature is called a “glass transition” and measured using calorimetry.

The goal of this project was to understand what factors influence the glass transition, such as moisture content or added salt so that others might use this knowledge for their own processing and application purposes. Complexes were prepared under various conditions, such as salt type, salt concentration, polyelectrolyte ratio, and temperature. In general, it was observed that added moisture and/or added salt decreased the glass transition temperature.

With regard to salt type, different anions and cations were added to the complex to investigate how ion type would change the glass transition temperature. It was determined that regardless of ion type, the mechanism of the material’s softening remained the same. Specifically, a linear equation the relates the glass transition temperature to the water content and the ion pair content was confirmed and proved universal for all salt types studied (Figure 2).

Besides moisture, it was also proved that softening of the complex could occur using alcohols. Alcohols can contain one, two, or three (or more) hydroxyl groups that can interact or hydrogen bond with the ion pairs. A series of alcohols with different number of hydroxyl groups was added to the complex, and the glass transition was measured. A linear equation was used to relate the glass transition number to the hydroxyl group content and the ion pair content (Figure 3).

These complexes can dissociate and transform from solid to liquid phases, or even dissolve. To study how these different phases might be related to the physical structure of the complex, a series of complexes was prepared at different conditions and observed using optical microscopy. A phase diagram was prepared at different temperatures to show that these phases can be erased or dissolved into solution if the temperature is raised (Figure 4).

The broader impact of this work is that these results have demonstrated the highly tunable nature of polyelectrolyte complexes and emphasize the boundaries at which they can be created and processed.

Through this project four graduate students, one post-doctoral researcher, and two undergraduate researchers were mentored. Graduates entered the workforce immediately into the chemical and semiconductor sectors.

Results were disseminated in peer-reviewed journal articles, conferences, and seminars.

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2025
Modified by: Jodie Lutkenhaus

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. A polyelectrolyte complex heated through its glass transition temperature (Tg) is thought to exhibit decreased water-polyelectrolyte hydrogen bonding lifetimes at the intrinsic ion pair, as well as weakened intrinsic ion pairing.
    JLL
    Public Domain
    Jodie Lutkenhaus
    Figure 1
  • a) UCST contour plot of PDADMA/PAA complexes at pH 3.22 with varying polyelectrolyte mixing ratio and KBr concentration. b) The effect of temperature on the phase map of PDADMA/PAA complexes. The scale bar represents 50 μm.
    JLL/ACS
    Creative Commons
    Jodie Lutkenhaus
    Figure 4
  • Linear fitting of ln(n_(H2 O)/n_(intrinsic ion pair) ) vs 1000/Tg for PDADMA-PSS PEC systems of varying salt concentrations (0.03 - 0.20 M) of CaCl2 and MgCl2 with NaCl as a control. n_H2O is the number of water molecules and n_intrinsic ion pair is the number positive-negative pairs.
    JLL/RSC Publishing
    Creative Commons
    Jodie Lutkenhaus
    Figure 2
  • Tg for PDADMA/PAA complexes for solvents with varying (a) liquid content, (b) moles of solvent molecules and (c) moles of available for solvation hydroxyl groups (two groups for diol molecules, one group for mono alcohol and water molecule).
    JLL/ACS
    Creative Commons
    Jodie Lutkenhaus
    FIgure 3

Polyelectrolyte complexes (PECs, Figure 1), which form when oppositely charged polymers associate to create a larger structure, are experiencing a renaissance, spurred by new processing approaches and applications. These postive-negative associations between the oppositely charged polymers are called ion-pairs.
